Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research In Neutrino Astrophysics at the University of Wisconsin-River Falls
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Wisconsin - River Falls to provide six undergraduates with ten-week summer research experiences annually on projects with data from the international IceCube Neutrino Observatory. To advance discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning, students will be integrated into a research collaboration that opened the field of neutrino astronomy, and work in a department where learning and involving undergraduates in research are priorities. Students will acquire a broad range of research skills, will learn to appreciate the value of fundamental science to society and will be mentored on giving effective scientific presentations and in communicating science.

Students will make contributions to the IceCube experiment that will help advance understanding and knowledge in the field of neutrino astronomy. IceCube is a unique telescope located at the South Pole. (However, students will not travel to the South Pole). Unlike traditional optical telescopes, IceCube looks at the universe via particles called neutrinos. Physics World deemed IceCube's observation of extraterrestrial neutrinos, a result that ushered in the era of neutrino astronomy, the physics breakthrough of the year 2013. With access to IceCube data, high performance computing resources, and personnel, the students will make real contributions while acquiring research skills that are transferrable to many fields of science, technology, and engineering. Under the guidance of faculty advisors who have many years of experience successfully supervising undergraduate research, students will contribute to resolving some of the biggest puzzles in particle astrophysics: the origin of high-energy cosmic rays, the nature of neutrino oscillations, and the composition of dark matter.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Neutrino astronomy, realized two years ago through IceCube’s observation of a very high energy neutrino candidate from an identified extraterrestrial source, has opened an exciting new window to the universe. Neutrinos are among the fundamental particles of nature and they can travel in undeflected paths across vast distances between galaxies. Hence, they are ideal cosmic messengers. The multi-faceted IceCube Neutrino Observatory, deployed deep in the glacial ice at the South Pole, has the potential to answer long standing diverse questions in nature, including where do high energy cosmic rays come from and on fundamental properties of neutrinos. Also deployed at the South Pole are two smaller detectors, neutron monitors, which observe the lowest energy cosmic rays, and are sensitive to variations in the rates at which they arrive at Earth due to solar activity. Participating in research in astrophysics, astronomy, and cosmic rays could inspire this generation of undergraduates to stay in the field and pursue science at the next level.

At the University of Wisconsin-River Falls REU Site in Neutrino Astrophysics we had, in the four years of the project, 21 undergraduate participants working on a wide variety of research projects in neutrino astrophysics connected with the IceCube Neutrino Observatory. Some students worked on projects related to the neutron monitors at the South Pole. REU participants came from a variety of types of institutions across the nation, including large research universities, and four and two-year colleges. Diversity and broadening participation in physics is a priority at the UWRF REU Site.

 IceCube collects vast amounts of data each year, around 100 billion things seen by the detector, from which around 100 neutrinos of direct astrophysical origin need to be found. Calibration projects sometimes require sophisticated computer simulations. REU participants working on IceCube require skills in analyzing large data sets and in complex simulations, both done using high performance computing. To get them up to speed with programming and data analysis, each year they attended a week-long astrophysics bootcamp at the Wisconsin IceCube Particle Astrophysics Center in Madison, WI. This bootcamp is a key component of the training aspect of the REU site.  Participants learned python programming, statistical methods in data analysis, and how to use the high-performance computing resources of IceCube. Many of these skills were then used in the summer projects. Some participants preferred more hands-on practical projects; they built prototypes of future detector components or characterized current components for calibration purposes.  REU participants had mentors both at UWRF and co-mentors from the wider IceCube community, with the intent being to expose them to the experience of working in a large scientific collaboration.

Apart form the training in computing and data analysis, participants attended workshops on scientific writing and poster presentations, the graduate school application process and GRE preparation, communicating science, and on research methods and resources in physics. There were many social activities, including field trips to state parks, kayaking, group dinners, and dinners at mentors’ homes. Each year’s cohort visited students at the UWRF Upward Bound program, where they described their backgrounds, and the path they took from high school to college physics.

UWRF’s involvement in the neutron monitor research provides a unique opportunity for undergraduate to deploy and conduct research at the South Pole. REU participants are included in the pool of students from which we select students for the South Pole. Two REU participants traveled to the South Pole in the four years of this project, and a third will deploy to the South Pole in the next southern summer.
